name: Terminating fixed point
intro: Per Raymond Smullyan's poetic definition, a bird y is said to be fond of
Equality here should usually be understood as action on appropriate number of arguments
rather than by composition, e.g. SK = KI because they act in the same way on two arguments.
As can be seen from the previous chapter, every bird is fond of at least one bird,
or every combinator has at least one fixed point.
However, it's not guaranteed to reach the normal form.
But in some cases it does, i.e. an equation of form f x = x
has a specific solution x for a given f.
Let's have a look on such special cases.

content.title: The Mockingbird's favourite
descr: Find x such that M x = x.
At least in this case, a solution exists that requires no additional arguments.

content.title: B simple
descr: Find x such that B x a b = x a b.
Since B requires 3 arguments to resolve into something else,
you'll need to provide two extra variables on the left, and, subsequently, on the right.
This logic applies to the following tasks as well.

content.title: Kestrel's affection
descr: Find x such that K x = x. It might be hiding among the above quests.
The theorem about the properties of every fixed point of K is one of the exercises
in To Mock A Mockingbird.
Unfortunately, the margins of this interpreter are too narrow to verify proofs...

content.title: Use the force, Luke
descr: Remember, T a b = b a. Find x such that T x = x.
Here you might need to resort to an actual fixed point calculation from the last chapter.

content.title: Cardinal
descr: Find x such that C x = x.
If you write down the YC a b, you'll get a and b
swapped forever in an infinite loop. You'll have to be clever...
content.hint: Can't make different variables indistinguishable? Discard them!

content.title: Starlink
descr: Find x such that S x = x.

content.title: Iota
descr: Given ι = z → x S K, find x such that ι x = x.
As of this writing, I have no idea how to solve it, aside from adding more variables
and cycling through x=K, x=S, x=Kx<sub>0</sub>, x=Sx<sub>1</sub>y<sub>1</sub>,
repeating the process for new unknowns if necessary.
I happen to know the solution by chance though.

content.title: Physician, heal thyself
descr: Oddly enough, the fixed point combinator itself has a terminating fixed point.
Find one!
